entries.title: Cubs run into bizarre triple play against Giants: 'Every day, you see something new'
entries.summary: <p>SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. – The inning was bizarre even by spring training standards.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a>’ 4-2 loss Sunday to the Giants began with a literal emergency alarm, running through parts of <b>Matt Shaw</b> and <b>Alex Bregmans</b>’ at-bats – It was definitely spring training, you know?” Bregman said – before spiraling into a triple play.</p><p>“I was confused about the fire drill, and then there’s three outs,” Cubs starting pitcher <b>Colin Rea</b> said. “And I’m like, ‘I don’t don’t know what just happened, but here we go.’”</p><p>With Cubs Shaw on second base and Bregman on first after both drawing walks, <b>Seiya Suzuki</b> blooped a single into shallow right field. Chaos ensued.</p><p>Giants second baseman <b>Luis Arraez</b> barehanded the ball on the bounce and tossed it home, prompting Suzuki to race for second. Giants first baseman <b>Rafael Devers</b> cut off the throw and fired.</p><p>One out.</p><p>Shaw had stopped in his tracks around third, while Bregman kept his head down and ran. They ended up on the same base.</p><p>"I thought I got a good read off the bat," Bregman said, "and then I should have ran a little bit more with my head up."</p><p>Giants shortstop <b>Willy Adames</b> ran over, tagged both runners, and handed the ball to third baseman <b>Matt Chapman</b>.</p><p>“I knew that, since I was the trail runner, I was out,” Bregman said. “But I’ve got to do a better job of just staying on the base, clarifying that.”</p><p>Two outs.</p><p>As Bregman headed to the dugout, correct in his assessment of the play, Shaw had a brief conversation with third-base coach <b>Quintin Berry</b>. Shaw stepped off the base, pulling off his sliding mitt and helmet as he talked. Chapman, still holding the ball, tagged him.</p><p>Three outs.</p><p>“I don’t know what happened,” Adames told Giants reporters. “That’s the beauty of baseball, I guess. Every day, you see something new.”</p><p>Said Bregman: “We'll learn from it.”</p><h3>Long set to see doctor</h3><p>The Cubs hope that<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/21/how-tokyo-series-prepared-cubs-matthew-boyd-for-wbc-ramp-up" > first baseman <b>Jonathon Long</b>’s left elbow sprain </a>isn’t serious enough to force him to withdraw from the World Baseball Classic, manager <b>Craig Counsell</b> said.</p><p>Long, a non-roster invitee, sustained the sprain Saturday in a collision Saturday during the Cubs’ game against the Rangers.</p><p>The Cubs shut him down from baseball activities Sunday, and he’s set to see a doctor Monday.</p><p>“He's sore today, and there's some swelling there today,” Counsell said. “But if it's just that, then, we're probably at two, three days [off] here.”</p><p>Long was scheduled to leave Cubs camp this week to join Team Chinese Taipei for the WBC.</p><h3>Gold for USA</h3><p>The Cubs were gathered in their clubhouse Sunday morning, with the TVs turned to the men’s hockey Olympic gold medal game between the United States and Canada, when Jack Hughes’ “golden goal” delivered the victory to the stars and stripes.</p><p>“We were all fired up,” said Bregman, who will be representing the US in the WBC this year. “We were going crazy in the clubhouse when we scored.”</p><p>Can that be replicated in the upcoming baseball tournament?</p><p>“Let's do it, let's go win,” Bregman said. “USA, baby.”<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Letter carrier union kicks off bargaining season with rally: 'First-class service deserves first-class pay'
entries.summary: <p>More than 100 workers with the National Association of Letter Carriers kicked off bargaining for their next contract Sunday with a rally, calling for fair wages and worker protections at the local branch’s Bronzeville headquarters. They were joined by Gov. JB Pritzker.</p><p>It comes after a year of attacks on federal workers' unions from the Trump administration, including the cancellation of several standing contracts.</p><p>The group is pushing for higher pay, a higher annual uniform allowance and safety measures for postal workers in the field in this new round of bargaining, which is expected to begin Wednesday, according to Elise Foster, president of NALC Branch 11.</p><p>Foster, a 30-year letter carrier from Pilsen, said postal workers often have to save up for years to get adequate uniforms to work outdoors through the city’s seasons. She said many union members are also concerned about safety after mail carrier Octavia Redmond was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2024/10/01/boy-15-charged-with-fatally-shooting-postal-worker-octavia-redmond-west-pullman" target="_blank" ><u>fatally shot two years ago</u></a>.</p><p>“These are some of the top key items even just to retain employees,” Foster said. “No one do what we do, the way we do it, that’s why first-class service deserves first-class pay. … We have to deliver ourselves back home to our families.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-ff0000" name="image-ff0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8f6f124/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd2%2F2c%2Fe25794db40b1a18d19ecd18f2eb1%2Fnalcrally-260223-05.jpg width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8b90d1e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd2%2F2c%2Fe25794db40b1a18d19ecd18f2eb1%2Fnalcrally-260223-05.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Gov. JB Pritzker raises his fist next to Elise Foster, president of NALC Branch 11, at a rally kicking off bargaining for the National Association of Letter Carriers at the union's Bronzeville headquarters Sunday, February 22, 2026. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8b90d1e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd2%2F2c%2Fe25794db40b1a18d19ecd18f2eb1%2Fnalcrally-260223-05.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b97d6e0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd2%2F2c%2Fe25794db40b1a18d19ecd18f2eb1%2Fnalcrally-260223-05.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8b90d1e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6000x3367+0+316/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd2%2F2c%2Fe25794db40b1a18d19ecd18f2eb1%2Fnalcrally-260223-05.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Gov. JB Pritzker raises his fist in solidarity next to Elise Foster, president of NALC Branch 11, at a rally kicking off bargaining for the National Association of Letter Carriers at the union’s Bronzeville headquarters. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Violet Miller/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>An agreement reached in March 2023 is set to expire near the end of May. It brought a new overtime pay structure and protections, increased wages with retroactive pay, cost-of-living adjustments and other changes.</p><p>But last year, then-Postmaster General Louis DeJoy agreed to work with the Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE, to make sweeping cuts to the postal service’s workforce and budget. DeJoy agreed to cut 10,000 letter carriers from the 640,000-person force and billions of dollars from the USPS budget</p><p>President Donald Trump has also repeatedly called for the privatization of USPS. Former FedEx board member and current Postmaster General David Steiner said he <a class="Link" href="https://apnews.com/article/us-postal-service-usps-steiner-mail-71bab75465eea7a50a065b5868ea96b6" target="_blank" ><u>plans to stay on the same track as DeJoy</u></a><u> </u>after DeJoy stepped down in late March 2025.</p><p>Trump has also waged a war on the unions representing federal workers, signing an executive order last March that said <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/illinois-governor/2025/08/14/jb-pritzker-union-protection-bills-trump-war-federal-unions" target="_blank" ><u>collective bargaining requirements no longer applied</u></a> to many federal agencies, impacting nearly a million employees at the time, according to the American Federation of Government Employees’ national office. Trump said the cancellations were allowed because the agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency, play a role in national security, a claim that labor groups are disputing in court.</p><p>Trump then canceled contracts for three agencies’ unions, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/environment/2025/08/12/president-donald-trump-union-contracts-chicago-us-environmental-protection-agency" target="_blank" ><u>stripping union protections</u></a> from EPA workers in August.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-a90001" name="image-a90001"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/86ebdd6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5522x3099+0+347/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fce%2F69%2F36cbc83a44b08d2baf4e580e5f04%2Fnalcrally-260223-07.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8674589/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5522x3099+0+347/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fce%2F69%2F36cbc83a44b08d2baf4e580e5f04%2Fnalcrally-260223-07.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d5749cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5522x3099+0+347/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fce%2F69%2F36cbc83a44b08d2baf4e580e5f04%2Fnalcrally-260223-07.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Workers with the National Association of Letter Carriers rally ahead of bargaining for their next contract Sunday, February 22, 2026." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d5749cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5522x3099+0+347/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fce%2F69%2F36cbc83a44b08d2baf4e580e5f04%2Fnalcrally-260223-07.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0c6ee9b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5522x3099+0+347/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fce%2F69%2F36cbc83a44b08d2baf4e580e5f04%2Fnalcrally-260223-07.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d5749cd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5522x3099+0+347/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fce%2F69%2F36cbc83a44b08d2baf4e580e5f04%2Fnalcrally-260223-07.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Workers with the National Association of Letter Carriers rally ahead of bargaining for their next contract Sunday. Their current contract, signed in 2023, is set to expire in late May.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Violet Miller/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Days later, Pritzker signed a state law replacing any repealed federal occupational safety standard with a state standard and ensuring workers are paid the Illinois prevailing wage whenever it is higher than the federal rate when federal construction projects are administered by a state or local government.</p><p>It was one of very few tools for state and local lawmakers looking to back unions against Trump’s gutting of their contracts.</p><p>After being introduced by Mack Julion, the union’s national assistant secretary, as the “48th president of the United States” — drawing a laugh from Pritzker — the governor said the federal government needed to stop working against the union.</p><p>Pritzker mentioned the late civil rights leader<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" > Jesse Jackson, who died last week,</a> saying that winning the contract would be the “best way to honor his memory.”</p><p>“The postmaster general needs to do right by you and get you the contract you deserve,” Pritzker said before exiting to chants of "48." “And we’re gonna have to yell it. … Every worker in the United States needs a better wage, so your fight is for them too.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-370001" name="image-370001"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e5a93ee/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5204x2921+0+227/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F6e%2Fe4aad3b846808628714d44fafb7a%2Fnalcrally-260223-12.jpg JB Pritzker speaks at a rally kicking off bargaining for the  National Association of Letter Carriers at the union's Bronzeville headquarters Sunday, February 22, 2026" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b26a79c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5204x2921+0+227/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F6e%2Fe4aad3b846808628714d44fafb7a%2Fnalcrally-260223-12.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bf71dda/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5204x2921+0+227/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F6e%2Fe4aad3b846808628714d44fafb7a%2Fnalcrally-260223-12.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b26a79c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5204x2921+0+227/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2F6e%2Fe4aad3b846808628714d44fafb7a%2Fnalcrally-260223-12.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p> “The postmaster general needs to do right by you and get you the contract you deserve,” Gov. JB Pritzker tells postal workers at a labor rally Sunday at the union’s headquarters in Bronzeville.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Violet Miller/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p>
